conclusion: The ring translates with velocity v through a magnetic field B, experiencing a motional electric field E = v × B.
With v along +x and B along –z, v × B points along +y with magnitude E = vB.
The part of the ring that has entered the field is the circular arc a … b subtending a central angle of 90°.
The polar angle φ of a point on the arc varies from φ = –45° (point b) to φ = +45° (point a).
Choose the path along the wire from b to a that lies wholly inside the field.
For a circular ring of radius R, the line element on the arc is dl = R(–sin φ î + cos φ ĵ) dφ.
The potential difference V_ab equals the line integral of the motional electric field along the conductor.
Calculate V_ab = ∫_b^a (E · dl) = vB R ∫_{–π/4}^{+π/4} cos φ dφ = vB R [sin φ]_{–π/4}^{+π/4} = vB R (√2/2 + √2/2) = √2 v B R.
The induced electric field points upward (+y), so positive charges are pushed toward a, making point a at higher potential.
Final result: V_a – V_b = √2 · B R v.
